questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling

Highyeild:

Diagnosis is based on the Rotterdam criteria. LH levels are elevated while FSH levels are normal. E1 is increased while E2 is normal. SHBG levels are decreased. DOC: OCPs DOC for infertility in PCOS: Letrozole

However, medical management is always tried as a conservative option before moving to invasive surgical procedures. Also, given the age of our patient here, option A is best avoided.

questions.text: Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by which of the following factors?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High level of Estrogen

Highyeild:

During pregnancy, the combination of estrogen and progesterone (produced by the placenta) circulating in the blood appears to inhibit milk secretion by blocking the release of prolactin from the pituitary gland and by making the mammary gland cells unresponsive to this pituitary hormone. The blockade is removed at the end of pregnancy by the expulsion of the placenta and the loss of its supply of hormones, as well as by the decline in hormone production by the ovaries, while sufficient estrogen remains in circulation to promote the secretion of prolactin by the pituitary gland and so favour lactation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA Main Hormonal Regulators of Lactogenesis and Excretion Hormone Origin in pregnancy Function Estrogen Placenta Stimulates the develop- ment of mammary tissue Oxytocin Neurohypophysis Stimulates the contrac- tion of smooth muscle to expel milk Progesterone Placenta Inhibits milk production Prolactin Adenohypophysis Stimulates lactogenesis by the mammary glands Prolactin- inhibiting hormone Placenta Renders the breast unresponsive to prolactin

questions.text: Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypomenorrhea

Highyeild:

Most patients with Asherman's syndrome experience menstrual blood flow that is sparse (hypomenorrhea) or absent (amenorrhea) along with increased cramping and abdominal pain. Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions or intrauterine synechiae) occurs when scar tissue forms inside the uterus and/or the cervix. These adhesions occur after surgery of the uterus or after a dilatation and curettage with tuberculosis and schistosomiasis being a less common cause. It occurs when trauma to or removal of the basal layer of endometrium in opposing areas within the uterine cavity. Such injury to the lining triggers inflammation that allows these adhesive bands to form from one side of the cavity to the other. Mild disease: few filmy adhesions involving less than a third of the uterine cavity with normal menses or hypomenorrhea. Moderate disease: filmy and dense adhesions, the involvement of one-third to two-thirds of the cavity, and hypomenorrhea. Severe disease: dense adhesions involving more than two-thirds of the cavity with amenorrhea. Although dilatation and curettage (D&C) are the most frequently used intervention for removing retained products of conception(RPOC), hysteroscopic resection, in comparison, is associated with lower rates of intrauterine adhesion formation. Hysteroscopic resection gives the advantage of direct visualization of the uterine chamber, thus allowing the removal of RPOC with minimal damage to the endometrium.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A 19-year-old female was brought to the OPD with a complaint of not having started menstruation with normal levels of LH and FSH. General examination shows normal breast and pubic hair. On pelvic examination blind ending vagina and uterus are not palpable. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mullerian agenesis Given is a case of MRKH (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome or bilateral mullerian duct agenesis).

Highyeild:

Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome refers to the congenital aplasia or severe hypoplasia of the structures that derive from the Mullerian ducts, including the upper vagina, uterus, and fallopian tubes. Bilateral Mullerian duct agenesis: Mullerian duct is absent so no fallopian tube (distal FT is present), uterus, cervix, vagina ⅔. Gonad: Ovary. A lower 1/3rd of the vagina is present (since it is from the urogenital sinus). Phenotype: female Karyotype: 46XX Clinical features: Primary amenorrhea in an otherwise normally developed adolescent female (typical initial presentation in MRKH). No menses (no uterus). No cyclic abdominal pain. Normal secondary sexual characteristics (breast development). Examination : P/V: blind pouch vagina USG: gonads present, no uterus Gold standard investigation: MRI Treatment: vaginoplasty (done just before or after marriage) Williams or Mcindoe’s

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

When physical examination findings are consistent with an absent or hypoplastic vagina , the immediate differential diagnosis includes MRKH and complete androgen insensitivity syndrome , which is due to an inactivating mutation in the androgen receptor.

Table:

#MANTRA MRKH AIS Genotype XX Genotype XY Normal female serum T levels Normal male T levels Normal female pubic and axillary hair Decreased pubic and axillary hair Normal female height Increased height compared with female counterparts Normal ovaries located high on the pelvic side wall Intra-abdominal testicles No increased risk of gonadal malignancy Gonads removal recommended after puberty due to increased risk of malignancy

questions.text: A 60-year-old female comes with post-menopausal bleeding, what investigation are you going to do?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endometrial tissue sampling

Highyeild:

For cases with PMB (postmenopausal bleeding), TVS (1 st line) > endometrial tissue sampling (2 nd line) is to be preferred to r/o endometrial malignancy. The endometrial thickness is measured in an anterior-posterior fashion, at the area of endometrial echo of maximal thickness, on a long-axis view of the uterus in TVS. An endometrial thickness of less than or equal to 4 mm has a negative predictive value greater than 99% for endometrial carcinoma. Findings on ultrasound for which endometrial sampling is indicated include: A thickened endometrial lining greater than 4 mm. Diffuse or focally increased echogenicity or heterogeneity. The inability to visualize the endometrium adequately. Endometrial sampling should also be obtained in patients with persistent or recurrent bleeding, even in the setting of a thin endometrial echo. It is reasonable, to begin with, endometrial sampling first rather than ultrasound, in patients with a higher pretest probability for malignancy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

The diagnostic accuracy of endometrial sampling correlates positively with the amount of tissue that is collected. If a subsequent transvaginal ultrasound shows a thin endometrium, and if bleeding has stopped, no further evaluation is necessary. A thickened endometrial echo may be caused, not by hyperplasia or malignancy, but by intracavitary lesions such as endometrial polyps. If ultrasound findings are suggestive of such lesions, or if there is a history-indicated suspicion (for example, prior polyps), additional imaging like saline-infusion ultrasonography or hysterosalpingogram may help to identify if a polyp or other intracavitary lesion is present.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

92

OGTT done twice, once at the first antenatal visit and again at 24-28 weeks. Insulin requirements will normally increase during the course of the pregnancy.

questions.text: Female with vaginal discharge with the strawberry cervix. DOC?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metronidazole

Highyeild:

Vaginitis Vaginitis Etiology Clinical Presentation Bacterial vaginosis ● Gardnerella vaginalis ● Symptoms o malodorous ("fishy" odour) vaginal discharge o not painful ● ● Physical exam o off-white or grey and thin vaginal discharge o normal vulva Vulvovaginal candidiasis ● Candida albicans ● Symptoms o pruritus and soreness o dyspareunia ● ● Physical exam o thick, white, odourless, and curd-like vaginal discharge o vulvar erythema and edema Trichomoniasis ● Trichomonas vaginalis ● Symptoms o Malodorous greenish discharge o Burning sensation o dyspareunia and dysuria o postcoital bleeding ● ● Physical exam o malodorous discharge o "strawberry" cervix o vulvovaginal erythema ● ● Important note o sexually transmitted; therefore, the partner must also be treated Metronidazole : First-line agent for both pregnant and nonpregnant women with bacterial vaginosis. First-line agent pregnant and nonpregnant women with Azoles ( Fluconazole, clotrimazole, miconazole ): First-line treatment option for women with vulvovaginal candidiasis. Topical azoles and not oral are preferred in pregnancy.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false.

questions.text: A 36-year-old G1P0 presents for the first prenatal visit in 12 weeks of pregnancy and came for USG with a history of passing bright red blood per vagina, on examination her uterus was 12 weeks size. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydatidiform mole

Highyeild:

Characteristic history and clinical findings along with the classic snowstorm appearance on USG are indicative of H. mole. It is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD). Transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS). Indication: β-hCG > 100,000 mIU/mL Findings: Central heterogeneous mass with numerous discrete anechoic “Snowstorm,” “cluster of grapes,” or “honeycomb” appearance on older ultrasounds. If partial mole: Fetal parts and amniotic fluid Abnormally wide gestational sac Abnormal-looking placenta Ovarian theca-lutein cysts More likely in complete mole

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA Feature Partial Mole Complete Mole Karyotype 69XXX or 69XXY 45XX or 46XY Pathology Fetus Amnion, fetal red blood cells Villous edema Trophoblastic proliferation Often present Usually present Variable, focal Focal, slight to moderate Absent Absent Diffuse Diffuse Clinical presentation Diagnosis Uterine size Theca lutein cysts Medical complications Postmolar invasion and malignancy Missed abortion Small or appropriate for gestational age Rare Rare <5% Molar gestation 50% large for gestational age >25% depending on diagnostic modality Becoming rare with early diagnosis 15% and 4%, respectively

questions.text: According to the latest WHO guidelines which maneuver should be done in 2nd stage of labour?

options.label: C
options.text: Hot compresses to prevent perineal tear

options.label: D
options.text: Maintain deflexed head and perineal support

questions.correct_answer: C. Hot compresses to prevent perineal tear
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hot compresses to prevent perineal tear

Highyeild:

Perineal massage with lubricants and warm compresses may soften and stretch the perineum and thus reduce the rate of 3rd and 4th-degree perineal tears. Episiotomy is NOT indicated routinely. It should be done only if indicated clinically. Delivery can be carried out in an upright or supine position if the lithotomy position cannot be tolerated by the patient. Deflexion of the head is NOT mandatory; as indicated in WHO guidelines. During the 1st stage of labour, maternal heart rate and blood pressure and fetal heart rate should be checked continuously by electronic monitoring or intermittently by auscultation, usually with a portable Doppler ultrasound device. Women may begin to feel the urge to bear down as the presenting part descends into the pelvis. However, they should be discouraged from bearing down until the cervix is fully dilated so that they do not tear the cervix or waste energy. During the 2nd stage of labour, perineal massage with lubricants and warm compresses can be used but precautions should be taken to reduce the risk of infection with a perineal massage. During the 2nd stage (in contrast to the 1st stage), the mother's position does not affect the duration or mode of delivery or maternal or neonatal outcome in deliveries without epidural anaesthesia. Also, the pushing technique (spontaneous versus directed and delayed versus immediate) does not affect the mode of delivery or maternal or neonatal outcome. Use of epidural anaesthesia delays pushing and may lengthen the 2nd stage by an hour.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and D are false.

questions.text: Which is the most effective emergency contraception under the government of India? Ethinylestradiol 600 mcg LNG 1.5 mg Ulipristal 30 mg Misoprostol 400 mcg Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 only

Highyeild:

The overall risk of having pregnancy after single unprotected intercourse is 8%. Emergency Contraception : Can be started up to five days (120 hours) after unprotected intercourse but the greatest protection occurs if it is given within 72 hours. Method of choice: Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose (0.75 mg 2 tablets together) One new pill available worldwide but not in India is Ella - 30 mg of ulipristal.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and D are false. A most effective method of emergency contraception (India): CuT> Ulipristal > LNG tablet However, Ulipristal is not currently available in India.

Extraedge:

Yuzpe method – OCP’s with 50 μg ethinyl estradiol 2 tablets twice 12 hours apart OCP’s with 30 μg EE – 4 tablets twice 12 hours apart Mifepristone (10 mg as soon as possible) Danazol Ulipristal (Synthetic Progesterone Receptor Modulator): Delays ovulation Dose: 30 mg, Single dose to be taken within 5 days. IUCD insertion within 5 days of unprotected sex. Centchroman 2 tablets (60 mg) twice 24 hours within 24 hours of intercourse.
